title: Why CEOs Cheat and What Happens When They Get Caught
description: More CEOs have been fired after getting caught having office romances. The CEOs of Nestle and Kohl's both left their jobs after having undisclosed romantic relationships. Astronomer CEO Andy Byron lost his job in July, after being caught in a clinch on a stadium ‘kiss cam’ with the technology firm’s chief people officer at a Coldplay concert. Bloomberg's Matthew Boyle has more on this disturbing trend. (Source: Bloomberg)
content: So you were living under a rock. You know this story in July when the astronomer CEO, Andy Byron, lost his job after he was caught on a kiss cam at a Coldplay concert. That kiss cam with a colleague. He's not alone. This week, Nestlé CEO lost his job over an office romance. In May, the CEO was fired over an undisclosed relationship with a vendor. So C-suite romances continue to cause turmoil atop some of the world's biggest companies. Matthew Boyle, Bloomberg senior management and workplace reporter, joins us now. I mean, Matthew, it's not like this is new, but the fact is really cropping up. It's like, why are these men doing this when they know it threatens not just their job but throws the entirety of the company into turmoil? I mean, it's funny, I asked an ethics professor this this very question yesterday, and she just sort of threw up her hands. She's like, honestly, it puzzles me. Do they just still think they're going to get away with it? Do they think they're untouchable? We don't really know. You kind of have to put these guys on the couch for a little while to to figure it all out. But these things still continue to happen. You wrote also a really good story not that long ago of just how expensive it is to get a new CEO. We've had some really high profile circumstances with that happening. Why isn't there more scrutiny? Why aren't there more companies trying to prevent this sort of thing from happening and having more clear guidelines because of the cost to the company? Yeah, I mean, I discovered that to bring in the new Starbucks CEO, for example, was it's $130 million proposition just to get that person in the door and the former CEO out the door. You know, they want a rockstar CEO sometimes. Maybe they don't do enough due diligence. I have talked to some companies that do a lot of digging around these CEO personalities, and they find that there often are red flags that get overlooked or a red flag that's just sort of downgraded to a yellow flag, let's say, because we really want this person in the seat. And you also wrote about these employee hotlines that are think are really fascinating. And I hadn't really been aware of these and the fact that they're getting more calls. What does it show about We see kind of the reported things, but what's actually happening underneath it? Exactly. It's a fascinating it's like a lot of elements of human resources. We don't really spend much time thinking about them, but they very much exist and they need to work. Well, there were 10,000 more calls to one vendor's hotline last year that I reported. And these investigations, it's great to have these hotlines, of course. But I also found, according to one survey from one of these hotline vendors, 38% of the investigations are just conducted according to suggested guidelines, and 4% had no guidelines whatsoever. They just they just swing it, you know? And so if you're not doing the investigation, what's the point of having the hotline? So, yeah, and also employees think they might get retaliated against as well. Matthew, I'm just listening to you. After the MeToo movement, after all of these high profile cases, it still doesn't seem like there's any real driving force to reform to change. Is that fair or is there anyone trying to lead the charge to say, hey, these workplace romances, they're not okay? And maybe it also underscores a lack of diversity. It's important to remember how rare this is, despite all the high profile since 2017 among big U.S. companies, 2500 CEO exits, less than 2% were due to allegations of misconduct. So let's remember, it's not happening as often as we think, despite Coldplay canoodling and all that. But yeah, you're right. You know, it still continues to happen. So, you know, and we thought MeToo would be the end of it. But of course, top people are still people.
summary: Bloomberg senior management and workplace reporter, Matthew Boyle, discusses the issue of C-suite romances at major companies, following the recent incident of the astronomer CEO, Andy Byron, who lost his job after being caught on a kiss cam at a Coldplay concert. This week, the Nestlé CEO lost his position due to an office romance, and in May, the CEO was fired over an undisclosed relationship with a vendor. Boyle asks why not more companies are being transparent about these issues and have clear guidelines about preventing such incidents. He also notes that employee hotlines are receiving more calls and that 38% of these investigations are conducted according to suggested guidelines, while 4% have no guidelines whatsoever. Despite these high-profile cases, there is no real driving force to reform the change.
shortSummary: Despite the MeToo scandal, CEO scandals like that involving CEOs are becoming more frequent, highlighting the high cost and perceived lack of proper due diligence in corporate leadership.
argos_summary: The article discusses a growing trend of CEOs being dismissed for office romances, citing recent cases at Nestlé, a technology firm, and Starbucks. Bloomberg’s Matthew Boyle highlights the high cost of replacing top executives and the lack of rigorous due diligence in hiring. He notes that while such scandals are rare—less than 2% of CEO exits involve misconduct—there is still insufficient scrutiny and unclear guidelines for handling these situations. The piece underscores the ongoing challenge of balancing executive talent with ethical standards in corporate governance.
